Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Additives for Stable, Low-Cost, and High-Performance Organic Electrochromic Windows
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impacts/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce initial building capital costs and monthly energy bills by providing dynamic glass at a price that is less than half that of the competition. Customers will experience a projected payback period of three years or less. Once the windows are installed, they will improve worker productivity because the windows can switch on the order of a few seconds in response to glare. The commercial impact of this work is significant because the amount of energy wasted by using standard, double pane windows costs $58 billion per year in the US. The company expects its windows will help reduce the energy waste at a low price such that the company can capture a significant portion of the $2 billion US construction glass market.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project involves improving the stability of electrochromic windows that can tint instantly. The fast switching speeds and low cost are due to a dramatically different set of materials that are similar to plastics. Although these materials can be deposited onto windows at a cost that is lower than competing technologies, these materials have suffered from stability issues. The company is developing anti-oxidant additives that can be used to improve the stability. Our research objectives are to produce devices with an accelerated lifetime of 20 years and to produce a 10 inch by 10 inch prototype that can used to create design pull amongst building design firms and building owners. This will allow the company to obtain third party validation, enlist channel partners, and begin scale-up.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NexTint produces a low-cost, electronically dimmable window film that can improve energy efficiency and occupant comfort. The tint of the film can be electronically controlled wirelessly through a web-based application. People have been wanting smart glass for a long time; however, current solutions are too expensive, until now. NexTint’s window film costs 5X – 7X less than existing competitors.

Our window film solves two big problems. The first problem is energy efficiency. If our window film were broadly implemented in the United States, the amount of energy that it would save is five quadrillion BTUs. This is approximately equal to one third of the electricity generated by coal power plants in the United States. The second problem that our product solves is glare control. People solve this problem with blinds but shades do not look nice and they are not energy efficient. Our dimmable window film is the elegant solution to the glare control problem.

NexTint window film can be applied in two ways. First, it can be applied directly to glass just like a regular window film. There is a small module in the corner that provides the power and the wireless connectivity to the film. The other way that our window film can be applied is by using a window-film insert through our partners, Clear-Wall. The window insert provides an air space between the glass and the window film, which takes the performance of a single pane window to beyond the performance of double pane.

We can install our window film for a price that is 5X-7X lower than the competition because we are using organic-based materials that can be easily dissolved into inks and printed on a massive scale, roll-to-roll. Our company will not have to build out a full factory because we can do the printing using other peoples’ equipment. In fact, as one of our goals for the NSF-Phase I SBIR, we produced working window films at the Kodak factory in Rochester NY. The main reason why nobody has been successful at this so far is because organic materials are perceived to be not stable. Organics are the same materials that are in plastics and dyes which tend to change color and degrade under UV light. Demonstrating long-term stability was one of the goals of our NSF Phase I SBIR.

The second goal during our Phase I SBIR was to show that our electrochromic window film could potentially withstand ten years of solar exposure and electrical cycling. To measure the stability, we used accelerated lifetime testing. Our test samples were exposed to concentrated, simulated sunlight, and cycled between the tinted and clear states at a rate that is ~10X greater. By exposing the devices to concentrated sunlight 24/7, and by rapidly switching the devices, we can simulate a year of operation in ~36 days.

We showed in our test a less than 2% degradation over the course of 1.6 years of equivalent testing. Assuming a linear degradation rate and no catastrophic failure, the lifetime for this device is in excess of ten years.

We dramatically improved the lifetime of our device by using superior encapsulants and a very stable material to perform the tinting. Typically UV-curable epoxies are used to seal these devices. These materials have a very high permeability to moisture and we used an adhesive that has 100X lower moisture permeability.

Although demonstrating this level of stability is unprecedented in the published work on organic-based electrochromics, there is still more work to be done.
